Situation1: Their parents directly open up about a personal struggle and look to them for comfort.
Expectation2: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation2: My dog becomes vocal in the hallway when people pass near shared doors.
Story: I was sitting on the couch, trying to focus on my homework, when my stepdad sat down beside me. His eyes looked tired, and he started talking about how overwhelmed he felt at work and how hard it was to connect with my mom lately. He needed someone to listen, to reassure him, and I could feel the weight of his words pressing on me. I wanted to be there for him, to show him he wasn’t alone, but just as he started to open up, my dog started barking loudly in the hallway. I knew Mrs. Lee next door hated the noise—she’d already left a note about it last week. I could hear her door creak open, probably to see what was going on. I felt torn, my stepdad’s voice growing more vulnerable while my dog’s barking echoed through the hall. Should I comfort my stepdad, or rush to quiet my dog before the neighbors got upset again? My heart pounded as I sat between the two worlds, feeling like I was letting someone down no matter what I did.
